Browse the source code of netbsd/external/bsd/ppp/dist/pppd/session.c

73#include <sys/cdefs.h>
74__RCSID("$NetBSD: session.c,v 1.4 2014/10/25 21:11:37 christos Exp $");
75
76
77#include <stdio.h>
78#include <stdlib.h>
79#include <string.h>
80#include <pwd.h>
81#ifdef HAS_SHADOW
82#include <shadow.h>
83#endif
84#include <time.h>
85#ifdef SUPPORT_UTMP
86#include <utmp.h>
87#endif
88#ifdef SUPPORT_UTMPX
89#include <utmpx.h>
90#endif
91#include <util.h>
92#include <fcntl.h>
93#include <unistd.h>
94#include "pppd.h"
95#include "session.h"
96
97#ifdef USE_PAM
98#include <security/pam_appl.h>
99#endif /* #ifdef USE_PAM */
100
101#define SET_MSG(var, msg) if (var != NULL) { var[0] = msg; }
102#define COPY_STRING(s) ((s) ? strdup(s) : NULL)
103
104#define SUCCESS_MSG "Session started successfully"
105#define ABORT_MSG "Session can't be started without a username"
106#define SERVICE_NAME "ppp"
107
108#define SESSION_FAILED 0
109#define SESSION_OK 1
110
111/* We have successfully started a session */
112static bool logged_in = 0;
113
114#ifdef USE_PAM
115/*
116 * Static variables used to communicate between the conversation function
117 * and the server_login function
118 */
119static const char *PAM_username;
120static const char *PAM_password;
121static int PAM_session = 0;
122static pam_handle_t *pamh = NULL;
123
124/* PAM conversation function
125 * Here we assume (for now, at least) that echo on means login name, and
126 * echo off means password.
127 */
128
129static int conversation (int num_msg,
130#ifndef SOL2
131 const
132#endif
133 struct pam_message **msg,
134 struct pam_response **resp, void *appdata_ptr)
135{
136 int replies = 0;
137 struct pam_response *reply = NULL;
138
139 reply = malloc(sizeof(struct pam_response) * num_msg);
140 if (!reply) return PAM_CONV_ERR;
141
142 for (replies = 0; replies < num_msg; replies++) {
143 switch (msg[replies]->msg_style) {
144 case PAM_PROMPT_ECHO_ON:
145 reply[replies].resp_retcode = PAM_SUCCESS;
146 reply[replies].resp = COPY_STRING(PAM_username);
147 /* PAM frees resp */
148 break;
149 case PAM_PROMPT_ECHO_OFF:
150 reply[replies].resp_retcode = PAM_SUCCESS;
151 reply[replies].resp = COPY_STRING(PAM_password);
152 /* PAM frees resp */
153 break;
154 case PAM_TEXT_INFO:
155 /* fall through */
156 case PAM_ERROR_MSG:
157 /* ignore it, but pam still wants a NULL response... */
158 reply[replies].resp_retcode = PAM_SUCCESS;
159 reply[replies].resp = NULL;
160 break;
161 default:
162 /* Must be an error of some sort... */
163 free (reply);
164 return PAM_CONV_ERR;
165 }
166 }
167 *resp = reply;
168 return PAM_SUCCESS;
169}
170
171static struct pam_conv pam_conv_data = {
172 &conversation,
173 NULL
174};
175#endif /* #ifdef USE_PAM */
176
177int
178session_start(flags, user, passwd, ttyName, msg)
179 const int flags;
180 const char *user;
181 const char *passwd;
182 const char *ttyName;
183 char **msg;
184{
185#ifdef USE_PAM
186 bool ok = 1;
187 const char *usr;
188 int pam_error;
189 bool try_session = 0;
190#else /* #ifdef USE_PAM */
191 struct passwd *pw;
192 char *cbuf;
193#ifdef HAS_SHADOW
194 struct spwd *spwd;
195 struct spwd *getspnam();
196 long now = 0;
197#endif /* #ifdef HAS_SHADOW */
198#endif /* #ifdef USE_PAM */
199
200 SET_MSG(msg, SUCCESS_MSG);
201
202 /* If no verification is requested, then simply return an OK */
203 if (!(SESS_ALL & flags)) {
204 return SESSION_OK;
205 }
206
207 if (user == NULL) {
208 SET_MSG(msg, ABORT_MSG);
209 return SESSION_FAILED;
210 }
211
212#ifdef USE_PAM
213 /* Find the '\\' in the username */
214 /* This needs to be fixed to support different username schemes */
215 if ((usr = strchr(user, '\\')) == NULL)
216 usr = user;
217 else
218 usr++;
219
220 PAM_session = 0;
221 PAM_username = usr;
222 PAM_password = passwd;
223
224 dbglog("Initializing PAM (%d) for user %s", flags, usr);
225 pam_error = pam_start (SERVICE_NAME, usr, &pam_conv_data, &pamh);
226 dbglog("---> PAM INIT Result = %d", pam_error);
227 ok = (pam_error == PAM_SUCCESS);
228
229 if (ok) {
230 ok = (pam_set_item(pamh, PAM_TTY, ttyName) == PAM_SUCCESS) &&
231 (pam_set_item(pamh, PAM_RHOST, ifname) == PAM_SUCCESS);
232 }
233
234 if (ok && (SESS_AUTH & flags)) {
235 dbglog("Attempting PAM authentication");
236 pam_error = pam_authenticate (pamh, PAM_SILENT);
237 if (pam_error == PAM_SUCCESS) {
238 /* PAM auth was OK */
239 dbglog("PAM Authentication OK for %s", user);
240 } else {
241 /* No matter the reason, we fail because we're authenticating */
242 ok = 0;
243 if (pam_error == PAM_USER_UNKNOWN) {
244 dbglog("User unknown, failing PAM authentication");
245 SET_MSG(msg, "User unknown - cannot authenticate via PAM");
246 } else {
247 /* Any other error means authentication was bad */
248 dbglog("PAM Authentication failed: %d: %s", pam_error,
249 pam_strerror(pamh, pam_error));
250 SET_MSG(msg, (char *) pam_strerror (pamh, pam_error));
251 }
252 }
253 }
254
255 if (ok && (SESS_ACCT & flags)) {
256 dbglog("Attempting PAM account checks");
257 pam_error = pam_acct_mgmt (pamh, PAM_SILENT);
258 if (pam_error == PAM_SUCCESS) {
259 /*
260 * PAM account was OK, set the flag which indicates that we should
261 * try to perform the session checks.
262 */
263 try_session = 1;
264 dbglog("PAM Account OK for %s", user);
265 } else {
266 /*
267 * If the account checks fail, then we should not try to perform
268 * the session check, because they don't make sense.
269 */
270 try_session = 0;
271 if (pam_error == PAM_USER_UNKNOWN) {
272 /*
273 * We're checking the account, so it's ok to not have one
274 * because the user might come from the secrets files, or some
275 * other plugin.
276 */
277 dbglog("User unknown, ignoring PAM restrictions");
278 SET_MSG(msg, "User unknown - ignoring PAM restrictions");
279 } else {
280 /* Any other error means session is rejected */
281 ok = 0;
282 dbglog("PAM Account checks failed: %d: %s", pam_error,
283 pam_strerror(pamh, pam_error));
284 SET_MSG(msg, (char *) pam_strerror (pamh, pam_error));
285 }
286 }
287 }
288
289 if (ok && try_session && (SESS_ACCT & flags)) {
290 /* Only open a session if the user's account was found */
291 pam_error = pam_open_session (pamh, PAM_SILENT);
292 if (pam_error == PAM_SUCCESS) {
293 dbglog("PAM Session opened for user %s", user);
294 PAM_session = 1;
295 } else {
296 dbglog("PAM Session denied for user %s", user);
297 SET_MSG(msg, (char *) pam_strerror (pamh, pam_error));
298 ok = 0;
299 }
300 }
301
302 /* This is needed because apparently the PAM stuff closes the log */
303 reopen_log();
304
305 /* If our PAM checks have already failed, then we must return a failure */
306 if (!ok) return SESSION_FAILED;
307
308#else /* #ifdef USE_PAM */
309
310/*
311 * Use the non-PAM methods directly. 'pw' will remain NULL if the user
312 * has not been authenticated using local UNIX system services.
313 */
314
315 pw = NULL;
316 if ((SESS_AUTH & flags)) {
317 pw = getpwnam(user);
318
319 endpwent();
320 /*
321 * Here, we bail if we have no user account, because there is nothing
322 * to verify against.
323 */
324 if (pw == NULL)
325 return SESSION_FAILED;
326
327#ifdef HAS_SHADOW
328
329 spwd = getspnam(user);
330 endspent();
331
332 /*
333 * If there is no shadow entry for the user, then we can't verify the
334 * account.
335 */
336 if (spwd == NULL)
337 return SESSION_FAILED;
338
339 /*
340 * We check validity all the time, because if the password has expired,
341 * then clearly we should not authenticate against it (if we're being
342 * called for authentication only). Thus, in this particular instance,
343 * there is no real difference between using the AUTH, SESS or ACCT
344 * flags, or combinations thereof.
345 */
346 now = time(NULL) / 86400L;
347 if ((spwd->sp_expire > 0 && now >= spwd->sp_expire)
348 || ((spwd->sp_max >= 0 && spwd->sp_max < 10000)
349 && spwd->sp_lstchg >= 0
350 && now >= spwd->sp_lstchg + spwd->sp_max)) {
351 warn("Password for %s has expired", user);
352 return SESSION_FAILED;
353 }
354
355 /* We have a valid shadow entry, keep the password */
356 pw->pw_passwd = spwd->sp_pwdp;
357
358#endif /* #ifdef HAS_SHADOW */
359
360 /*
361 * If no passwd, don't let them login if we're authenticating.
362 */
363 if (pw->pw_passwd == NULL || strlen(pw->pw_passwd) < 2)
364 return SESSION_FAILED;
365 cbuf = crypt(passwd, pw->pw_passwd);
366 if (!cbuf || strcmp(cbuf, pw->pw_passwd) != 0)
367 return SESSION_FAILED;
368 }
369
370#endif /* #ifdef USE_PAM */
371
372 /*
373 * Write a wtmp entry for this user.
374 */
375
376 if (SESS_ACCT & flags) {
377 if (strncmp(ttyName, "/dev/", 5) == 0)
378 ttyName += 5;
379#ifdef SUPPORT_UTMP
380 logwtmp(ttyName, user, ifname); /* Add wtmp login entry */
381#endif
382#ifdef SUPPORT_UTMPX
383 logwtmpx(ttyName, user, ifname, 0, USER_PROCESS); /* Add wtmpx login entry */
384#endif
385
386 logged_in = 1;
387
388#if defined(_PATH_LASTLOG) && !defined(USE_PAM)
389 /*
390 * Enter the user in lastlog only if he has been authenticated using
391 * local system services. If he has not, then we don't know what his
392 * UID might be, and lastlog is indexed by UID.
393 */
394 if (pw != NULL) {
395 struct lastlog ll;
396 int fd;
397 time_t tnow;
398
399 if ((fd = open(_PATH_LASTLOG, O_RDWR, 0)) >= 0) {
400 (void)lseek(fd, (off_t)(pw->pw_uid * sizeof(ll)), SEEK_SET);
401 memset((void *)&ll, 0, sizeof(ll));
402 (void)time(&tnow);
403 ll.ll_time = tnow;
404 (void)strncpy(ll.ll_line, ttyName, sizeof(ll.ll_line));
405 (void)strncpy(ll.ll_host, ifname, sizeof(ll.ll_host));
406 (void)write(fd, (char *)&ll, sizeof(ll));
407 (void)close(fd);
408 }
409 }
410#endif /* _PATH_LASTLOG and not USE_PAM */
411 info("user %s logged in on tty %s intf %s", user, ttyName, ifname);
412 }
413
414 return SESSION_OK;
415}
416
417/*
418 * session_end - Logout the user.
419 */
420void
421session_end(const char* ttyName)
422{
423#ifdef USE_PAM
424 int pam_error = PAM_SUCCESS;
425
426 if (pamh != NULL) {
427 if (PAM_session) pam_error = pam_close_session (pamh, PAM_SILENT);
428 PAM_session = 0;
429 pam_end (pamh, pam_error);
430 pamh = NULL;
431 /* Apparently the pam stuff does closelog(). */
432 reopen_log();
433 }
434#endif
435 if (logged_in) {
436 if (strncmp(ttyName, "/dev/", 5) == 0)
437 ttyName += 5;
438#ifdef SUPPORT_UTMP
439 logwtmp(ttyName, "", ""); /* Wipe out utmp logout entry */
440#endif
441#ifdef SUPPORT_UTMPX
442 logwtmpx(ttyName, "", "", 0, DEAD_PROCESS); /* Wipe out utmpx logout entry */
443#endif
444 logged_in = 0;
445 }
446}
447
